the rest of the series - And it is curious to remark that 
throughout, the outer and inner membranes appear to bear 
the same physiological relation to one another as do the 
serous & mucous layers of the germ - The outer, becoming 
developed into the muscular system and giving rise to the 
organs of offence and defence; - The inner, on the other hand 
appearing to be more closely subservient to the purposes of 
nutrition and generation 
[paragraph].59. The structure of the stomach in the <u>Medusae<\u> is in general 
identical with that of the same organ in the rest of the 
series - The <u>Rhizostomidae<\u> offer an apparent difficulty 
but it appears to me that the marginal folds in these 
answer to the stomacal membrane of the <u>monostome<\u> Medusae 
the apertures to the inner orifice of their stomach - and 
the common canal to their "common cavity" - Just as 
in a polygastric <u>Diphyes<\u> the common tube answers to the 
chamber into which the stomach of a monogastric Diphyes 
opens - And in Cephea Wagneri (Will) these resemblances 
are still more striking - He says that each cotyledon "has at its 
apex a small round opening, the mouth, which leads to an ovate 
cavity occupying the whole interior of the cotyledon - I consider this as 
the proper digestive or stomacal cavity and believe that the cotyledons 
have the same relation to the vessels as the so called suckers (Saugrohren) 
of the Diphydae to the common tube (Saftrohren)". * 
[paragraph].60. The Disc of a <u>Medusa<\u> is represented by the Natatorial organ 
among the Diphydae & Physophoridae - take for instance the 
disc of <u>Oceania<\u> or <u>Cytaeis<\u> - It is here a more or less bell shaped 
* Horae Tergutinae. p. 60.
